body:
Same thing happens on SQL server as well. Problem is with 

```SQL
INSERT INTO fit3.product(config) VALUES ('null');
```

Given that owned entity should be stored there, we expect either a JSON object or null value. 'null' in this context is invalid JSON

@maumar isn't `null` is valid JSON (just like the null in `{ "a" : null }`? In other words, there are two ways to represent null here, relational NULL (where the entire column value is NULL), or JSON null (where the column is a non-null string containing `null` - again just like we represent null for nested JSON owned entities).

Note that it's technically possible to also have something like `[1, 2, 3]`, or even `3` or `true`. These would be perfectly valid JSON, but of course would be invalid for EF in a place where we expect an owned entity (in that context, only a JSON object or null are valid). This again is the same regardless of whether the invalid value appears at the top-level JSON entity, or nested (e.g. `{ "a": 8 }` where `a` is modeled in EF to be an owned entity).

Exactly what @roji said - there are 2 ways to represent null values (relational NULL and JSON null).

Is the behavior that I described a bug in EF Core? Are there any workarounds that allow us to query the data without encountering exceptions?

@maumar Thank you for the workaround idea, but projecting all the fields in a class with 30+ properties (database columns) and then mapping them back to the original type can become very unmaintainable and tedious. Moreover, as you said, entity tracking is lost.

If there are no other options, we will wait for an official fix, but this bug prevents us to perform _the most basic_ queries in our production application (for example, `_cntx.Products.ToList()`). This is a blocker for us.

issue.title: Fix to #34960 - System.Text.Json.JsonReaderException: '0x00' is invalid after a single JSON value. Expected end of data

repository.name: efcore
repository.description: EF Core is a modern object-database mapper for .NET. It supports LINQ queries, change tracking, updates, and schema migrations.

issue.body:
When entity or collection of entities is mapped to JSON null value for that object can be represented either as relational null, or as JSON with null value inside 'null'. Problem was that IncludeJsonEntityReference and IncludeJsonEntityCollection were only checking for null value, and not for the JSON 'null'. (MaterializeJsonEntity and MaterializeJsonEntityCollection had the logic for both)

Fix is to add the missing logic so that upon encountering Null token we just return, rather than run shaper code for the entity. Also added some validation that throws if StartObject is not the first token (again, copying logic from MaterializeJsonEntity method)

Fixes #34960
